Welcome to the world of rhythm! The pulse is like the heartbeat of music. It is a series of constant beats that mark the time. Try clapping along to a steady beat!
The measure groups these pulses. The most common is 4/4, which means there are 4 pulses in each musical \'box\' or measure. The first pulse is usually the strongest: ONE, two, three, four.
Figures tell us how long a sound should last.\n\nThe WHOLE NOTE lasts for 4 pulses. It\'s the longest!
The HALF NOTE lasts for half of a whole note, that is, 2 pulses.
The QUARTER NOTE lasts for 1 pulse. It is the most common figure to follow the rhythm.
The EIGHTH NOTE lasts for half a pulse. It\'s faster! Two eighth notes are needed to fill one quarter note pulse.
Music is also made of silences. Each note figure has its own rest, which lasts exactly the same amount of time.\n\nThe whole rest also lasts for 4 pulses of silence.
The half rest lasts 2 pulses. The quarter rest, 1 pulse, and the eighth rest, half a pulse. Silence is as important as sound!
The staff is those 5 lines and 4 spaces where we write music. It\'s like the ruler for musical notes!

The Treble Clef is a symbol placed at the beginning of the staff. Its function is very important: it gives the notes their names! The \'belly\' of the clef wraps around the second line, telling us that this line is called G.
The notes on the lines, counting from the bottom up, are: E, G, B, D, F.
The notes in the spaces, counting from the bottom up, spell the word: F, A, C, E.
